q: What are the risk factors for diabetic retinopathy?
a: Risk factors for diabetic retinopathy include having diabetes for a long time, persistently high blood sugar levels, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, being pregnant, and having Asian or Afro-Caribbean background.

q: How can diabetes affect the eyes?
a: Diabetes can affect the eyes by damaging the blood vessels in the retina, which can lead to diabetic retinopathy. This can cause vision problems and, if left untreated, blindness.

q: What are the symptoms of diabetic retinopathy?
a: Symptoms of diabetic retinopathy may include gradually worsening vision, sudden vision loss, floaters in your field of vision, blurred or patchy vision, eye pain or redness, and difficulty seeing in the dark.

q: What is diabetic eye screening?
a: Diabetic eye screening is a test offered to people with diabetes aged 12 and over. It involves examining the back of the eyes and taking photographs to detect any signs of diabetic retinopathy.

q: How often should I have diabetic eye screening?
a: The frequency of diabetic eye screening depends on your last 2 screening results. If no diabetic retinopathy was found in your last 2 tests, you'll be invited for screening every 2 years.

q: How can I reduce my risk of diabetic retinopathy?
a: You can reduce your risk of diabetic retinopathy by controlling your blood sugar, blood pressure, and cholesterol levels, attending all your screening appointments, seeking medical advice for any changes to your vision, maintaining a healthy lifestyle, and not smoking.

q: Are there any treatments for diabetic retinopathy?
a: If diabetic retinopathy reaches a stage where vision is at risk, treatments such as laser treatment, injections of medication into the eyes, or an operation to remove blood or scar tissue may be necessary. Otherwise, managing diabetes is recommended.

q: What are the stages of diabetic retinopathy?
a: The stages of diabetic retinopathy include background retinopathy, pre-proliferative retinopathy, and proliferative retinopathy. These stages involve changes in the blood vessels of the retina and can lead to vision loss if not treated.

q: Can diabetic retinopathy be detected in the early stages?
a: Diabetic retinopathy may not have obvious symptoms in the early stages, but it can be detected through diabetic eye screening, which involves taking photographs of the eyes.

q: What should I do if I notice changes to my vision?
a: If you notice changes to your vision, such as worsening vision or sudden loss of vision, it is important to contact your GP or diabetes care team immediately for further evaluation.

q: What are the stages of diabetic retinopathy?
a: The stages of diabetic retinopathy are background retinopathy, pre-proliferative retinopathy, and proliferative retinopathy.

q: What can happen if diabetic retinopathy is left untreated?
a: If left untreated, diabetic retinopathy can cause blindness.

q: How can people with diabetes minimize the risk of diabetic retinopathy?
a: People with diabetes can minimize the risk of diabetic retinopathy by controlling their blood sugar levels, blood pressure, and cholesterol, as well as attending diabetic eye screening appointments.

q: Can anyone develop diabetic retinopathy?
a: Yes, anyone with type 1 or type 2 diabetes is potentially at risk of developing diabetic retinopathy.

q: What are the symptoms of diabetic retinopathy?
a: Symptoms of diabetic retinopathy include gradually worsening vision, sudden vision loss, floaters, blurred or patchy vision, eye pain or redness, and difficulty seeing in the dark.

q: What is the purpose of diabetic eye screening?
a: The purpose of diabetic eye screening is to detect problems in the eyes before they start to affect vision, as diabetic retinopathy does not tend to cause symptoms in the early stages.

q: How often should someone with diabetes attend diabetic eye screening?
a: The frequency of diabetic eye screening invitations depends on the last 2 screening results. If no diabetic retinopathy was found, the person is invited every 2 years.

q: How can someone reduce their risk of developing diabetic retinopathy?
a: To reduce the risk of diabetic retinopathy, one can control blood sugar, blood pressure, and cholesterol levels, take prescribed diabetes medicine, attend all screening appointments, seek medical advice for any changes in vision, maintain a healthy weight, eat a balanced diet, exercise regularly, and stop smoking.

q: When is treatment necessary for diabetic retinopathy?
a: Treatment for diabetic retinopathy is necessary if screening detects significant problems that put vision at risk.

q: What are the main treatments for diabetic retinopathy?
a: The main treatments for diabetic retinopathy are laser treatment, injections of medication into the eyes, and surgery to remove blood or scar tissue from the eyes.
